response.answer_text: Abortion always causes death. Except in the very rare cases when the abortion is botched. The purpose of an abortion is to kill. A vulnerable and defenseless infant. The first measure of success in an abortion is that the killing was successful. The baby is dead. A secondary measure of success is that the mother is not dead. The third priority is that the mother recovers from the process without excessive bleeding, infection, or permanent damage to her body. The measure of success in an abortion never involves long-term impact on the mother. Such as depression. Sadness. Guilt. Decline in temperament and attitude. Or suicide. Even though a common result of abortion is a second death, by suicide. Six times as common among mothers who have killed their babies, as among mothers who have delivered their babies. An alternate form of a second death from abortion is the child from the woman’s second pregnancy. And the third. And so on. A woman who has killed the child of her first pregnancy, is exceedingly likely to have one or more additional abortions, killing her successive children. Or were you just selfishly worrying about death to the mother, during any abortion procedure? Medical or surgical abortion is quite unlikely to kill a woman during the procedure, if it is done by a qualified physician in a proper clinical setting. Just as normal delivery is quite unlikely to kill a woman, during a normal delivery. 700 a year, on average, out of four million live births. Way less than a hundredth of one percent. But since not all abortions are performed by qualified physicians in a proper setting, the fact is that maternal deaths due to abortion are distressingly frequent. Women still try to perform abortions themselves, which probably has around a 50% fatality rate. And women still go to abortion midwives, and to non-licensed abortion doctors, where the fatality rate is also appalling. Of course, the major concern when a women recognizes she has become pregnant should not be about preserving the mother’s life. Nor about preserving her lifestyle, and her comforts and her pleasures and her self-indulgences. The main concern ought to be the maintaining the life and health of her baby. And that should make abortion abhorrent to all women. Unfortunately, far too many women do think first about themselves, their life and their lifestyle. Abortions are done, when a woman decides the life of a baby, her baby, is less important than maintaining her lifestyle. A grotesque tradeoff. The ultimate act of selfishness. Particularly when most commonly, the woman’s lifestyle is generally ruined anyway, even after a successful abortion, by enduring feelings of guilt, remorse, and shame. So yes, abortion does cause death. Death first of the infant, but very frequently thereafter, also death of the mother. She may die from a non-medically conducted procedure, or from suicide. Or — often — from self-destruction of her being, through recognizing that she intentionally murdered her own child. Her life is not worth anything after that.

Generally speaking, lacking a central nervous system, or major components thereof, doesn’t top that list- at least for vertebrates. And since we’re mammalian- I presume we’re speaking of mammals; I didn’t stumble onto an amphibian/reptilian discussion did I?- we usually grow our young inside the host body, meaning that it’s not one potential member of the species who is affected, but two; and what occurs within the host body absolutely impacts their health, up to and including severe distress and death. If anything, proper abortive methods or D&E further advance the health of the host in present era than anything else, further enabling the potential to advance the species- that’s the whole point, right? Keep poppin’ out babies, populate the human race, diversify our potential to survive a changing world with new ideas and perspectives on how to improve life? It’s not?? Color me surprised.
